moves.1. Nf3: I'm back after a chess break.  Here is a game I played on the ICC at a 1 minute time control.
moves.1... d5: The main line Reti, however, this can transpose into the Catalan or after 3. d4 any number of 1. d4 lines.
moves.2. c4: Khalifman and Kramnik both recommend 2. d4 here, as 2...d4 (a reverse Benoni) can be a little uncomfortable if you are not used to it, however, the extra tempo only benefits white.
moves.2... dxc4: Black chooses to abandon the center and maybe try to hold the pawn.
moves.3. e4:
A little played continuation, which Nigel Davies advocates in his book on the Reti and a continuation that I employ frequently for its shock value.

3. e3 would lead to lines similar to the QGA.
moves.3... c6:
Trying to hold the pawn with 3...b5 is to weakening after 4. a4 c6; 5. ab cb; 6. b3!

3...Nf6; 4. Bxc4 Nxe4? and white can recover the pawn with a cute little tactic.  Can you figure it out?

The correct move is 3...c5, taking advantage of the dark-squared weakness.
moves.4. Bxc4: White's position is being readied for a direct assault on the black king.
moves.4... e6: Black falls further behind in development.  4...Nf6 was probably better.
moves.6... Ne7: Black's development is a little cramped.
moves.7... O-O: Not a bad move, but in this quick time control, the attack will be very quick.
moves.8... Na6: ??  Allowing the Greek Gift sacrifice on h7.
moves.9. e5: Clearing the line to h7 with tempo.
moves.10... Kxh7: After 10...Kh8; 11. Ng5 g6; 12. Qf3 Nf5; 13. Bxg6! decides the game in White's favor.
moves.11... Kg8: 11...Kg6 is the best defense, however, it still loses after 12. Qg4.
moves.14. Qh5+: The standard mating mechanism in this position.
moves.15. Qh7+: Here I let the ball drop, White is still winning, but Black can forstall mate by sacrificing material.
moves.17... Qe7: ?????? 17...Nh6 keeps him afloat for a little while longer.
